answers.answer: I'm new to Hash's but I think you should have the thyriod ultrasound at least.I had trouble shallowing for several, several years and my doctor told me it was from acid reflux.Endo did an ultrasound after a referral, finding that my primary doctor was under treating my thyroid. I hadn't had one in 6 years. The new ultrasound showed that I had a goiter, scar tissue and cysts.
What are the reference ranges on your FT3 and FT4?  These vary from lab to lab and have to come from your own lab report.
Unfortunately I only got the results by phone today, no hard copy as yet, and they did not read me the reference ranges but only told me the T3 was too low.

The range on FT4 is often about 0.8-1.8.  If that's the case with your lab, then you are right at the top of the range.  FT3 does look low, and Armour (dessicated) would improve your FT3 level and the balance between FT3/FT4.  You should do some research on dessicated since the formulas of both Armour and NatureThroid were changed last year, and many of our members find they do not work as well for them as they used to.  Many have started taking ERFA from Canada, which they find a better alternative at this point. Check the archives.You should also work on getting your vitamin D up.An ultrasound is pretty standard testing with Hashi's.  I agree that you ought to have a U/S to check for nodules, etc.  Hoarseness, fullness in the throat and difficulty swallowing are all associated with Hashi's (nodules, goiter, etc.).The enzyme (5' deiodinase) that is responsible for converting T4 to T3 is a selenium-based enzyme.  So, if you are deficient in selenium, conversion could be impeded.  If you are deficient, I don't see where correcting a deficiency is going to cause diabetes.I think you should proceed with U/S and selenium testing.  If selenium checks out fine, then give dessicated a shot. You're very lucky your doctor is paying attention to FT3 as many of them want to ignore it.

Thank you for all the information and suggestions.  I will find someone to order the ultrasound and will try the Armour.  It is good information that there are alternatives in Canada that might work better if the Armour doesn't work satisfactorily.  I will check the archives to see what is there.Also plan to ask for a selenium check.  I think this particular doctor is cautious in prescribing certain supplements due to possible side effects.  I am wondering if those on this forum think an endocrinologist would be more at ease with the ultrasound and the selenium.  I haven't seen one and wasn't sure there was a need as yet.  Perhaps I need to rethink that.  How does one decide when to see one? Aren't they for more complicated cases?

Just be aware that having the Endo after their name does not guarantee a good thyroid doctor.  Many specialize in diabetes, not thyroid.  Many have the "Immaculate TSH Belief", and do not want to test for FT3, and sometimes even FT4.  Many also are still using the old range of TSH, and have no idea about the need to reduce the ranges for FT3 and FT4, or at least use the current ranges as only guidelines within which to adjust levels as necessary to relieve symptoms.  Probably even fewer want to treat a patient for symptoms, relying instead on blood test results, as I discussed above.AS long as your doctor is willing to test for FT3 and FT4, and consider using a med other than a T4 type, then I think you would be best served staying with that doctor, as long as willing to treat your symptoms, rather than going by blood test levels only.  JMHO

It is good to know the biases of some endos.  Will keep that filed away then in case I need to interview one.  I see two listed in an adjacent area and one claims their special interest is thyroid, the other claims thyroid and adrenal.I am very aware that not every doctor is a good fit.  Sometimes they can only go along with you on a journey so far before their own insecurities or biases get in the way of your tx. I think on first meeting a lot can be determined if the right questions are asked.That said I do think you are right about the current doctor.   He definitely is willing to think outside the box.  I just hope he is willing to step outside his comfort zone andconsider selenium if needed.  I am wondering if anyone on the forum has used selenium, if so in what context and if they had any rise in blood sugar.Thanks for your response!  Good points.  Marie

question: I have been on synthroid for over 4 decades and was dx with Hashimoto's.  Two years ago the dose was lowered to .125 mg.My latest thyroid tests showed antibodies..TSH .45Free T4 1.8Free T3 2.0My doctor wants to put me on Armour.  He will not consider selinium because he is concerned it will cause diabetes.My vitamen D showed low as well.I have had  a recent dx of pure autonomic failure.  I have arthritis and gout.  I have dry skin, thinning eyebrows, and difficulty swallowing and a feeling of fullness in my throat.Sometimes I have stridor asnf my voice gets hoarse.My doctor does not want to do a thyroid ultrasound as he thinks the swallowing might be neurological.  I wonder if I may have thyroid nodules and I also wonder if my T3 is low due to low selenium levels.  Selenium has not been tested.Not sure how to proceed.
title: Low T3
